articles.headline: Keeping Faith in a Venture Built on Faith
articles.snippet: Born during the dot-com boom, beliefnet is a company that by all rights should have died with all the other failed ventures when the bubble burst.
articles.abstract: Born during the dot-com boom, beliefnet is a company that by all rights should have died with all the other failed ventures when the bubble burst.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I found the Chapter 11 period exhilarating,” Steven Waldman was saying the other day.

articles.headline: A Split Emerges as Conservatives Discuss Darwin
articles.snippet: A dispute has cropped up on the right: Does Darwinian theory actually support conservative philosophy?
articles.abstract: A dispute has cropped up on the right: Does Darwinian theory actually support conservative philosophy?
articles.lead_paragraph: Evolution has long generated bitter fights between the left and the right about whether God or science better explains the origins of life. But now a dispute has cropped up within conservative circles, not over science, but over political ideology: Does Darwinian theory undermine conservative notions of religion and morality or does it actually support conservative philosophy?

articles.headline: Paper Jam at FedEx Kinko’s
articles.snippet: Kinko’s metamorphosis from a free-wheeling group of copy centers to a buttoned-down subsidiary of FedEx is not going off without a hitch.
articles.abstract: Kinko’s metamorphosis from a free-wheeling group of copy centers to a buttoned-down subsidiary of FedEx is not going off without a hitch.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Tag along and marvel as Kenneth A. May, the chief executive of FedEx Kinko’s, works a roomful of employees.

articles.headline: In French Bid, Immigrant’s Son Battles Reputation as Anti-Immigrant
articles.snippet: Nicolas Sarkozy, the possible next president of France, has done as much, if not more, than any other French official to improve the status of minorities.
articles.abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy, the possible next president of France, has done as much, if not more, than any other French official to improve the status of minorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 4 — The possible next president of France is the son of an immigrant with a very un-French name who has done as much, if not more, than any other French official to improve the status of minorities.

articles.headline: Small Businesses’ Premiums Soar After Illness
articles.snippet: Small businesses may become a central issue in the debate over the problem of Americans without health insurance.
articles.abstract: Small businesses may become a central issue in the debate over the problem of Americans without health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand the challenges of insuring the health of the nation’s work force, consider Varney’s Book Store.

articles.headline: Proposed Media Deals Signal Upheavals in Financial News
articles.snippet: The future of financial news may lie in its global reach, supplied by media giants and distributed digitally.
articles.abstract: The future of financial news may lie in its global reach, supplied by media giants and distributed digitally.
articles.lead_paragraph: The future of financial news may lie in its global reach, supplied by media giants and distributed digitally. If so, there is still the question of which media giants will thrive.

articles.headline: Rumors Fly on Microsoft and Yahoo
articles.snippet: Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google.
articles.abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 — Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google, people briefed on the talks said Friday.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Propaganda Fear Cited in Account of Iraqi Killings
articles.snippet: Documents suggest that senior U.S. officers saw civilian deaths in Haditha as a problem requiring a misleading response.
articles.abstract: Documents suggest that senior U.S. officers saw civilian deaths in Haditha as a problem requiring a misleading response.
articles.lead_paragraph: Recently unclassified documents suggest that senior officers viewed the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in late 2005 as a potential public relations problem that could fuel insurgent propaganda against the American military, leading investigators to question whether the officers’ immediate response had been intentionally misleading.

articles.headline: Dear S.E.C., Reconsider Arbitration
articles.snippet: Arbitration was sold to investors as a cheap and fast alternative to the court system. But it has grown more costly and time-consuming.
articles.abstract: Arbitration was sold to investors as a cheap and fast alternative to the court system. But it has grown more costly and time-consuming.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARGUING that it is wrong to force investors into arbitration when resolving disputes with their brokers, two prominent United States senators have asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to ban the Wall Street practice of requiring customers to sign away their rights to bring their grievances to court.

articles.headline: What to Do When Rupert Calls?
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch may be the perfect publisher for The Wall Street Journal. Let me explain.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch may be the perfect publisher for The Wall Street Journal. Let me explain.
articles.lead_paragraph: I DON’T regularly watch the Fox News Channel, but when I do, I hardly think it is “fair and balanced.” I confess to reading The New York Post, but more as a delicious treat than a trusted news source. When I lived in London, I picked up The Times of London on my way to work every morning, but felt that the once-august publication had moved a bit down-market.

articles.headline: Torn From Parents, a Top Speller Vents His Anger, Letter by Letter
articles.snippet: Kunal Sah hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will help bring his parents back from India.
articles.abstract: Kunal Sah hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will help bring his parents back from India.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREEN RIVER, Utah — Great spellers come in all types, from egotistical showoffs to loners who find sanctuary in the forest of words.

articles.headline: Businesses Try to Make Money and Save the World
articles.snippet: Hundreds of new businesses around the country demonstrate an emerging convergence of for-profit money-making and nonprofit mission.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of new businesses around the country demonstrate an emerging convergence of for-profit money-making and nonprofit mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTRUSHARE SECURITIES is a brokerage firm, engaged in the sort of things you might expect of a Wall Street outfit, like buying and selling stock, and providing research on companies. Unlike its peers, however, the firm is majority-owned by two charities that each control about one-third of it.

articles.headline: From China to Panama, a Trail of Poisoned Medicine
articles.snippet: A poisonous solvent sold by counterfeiters and mixed into drugs has figured in mass poisonings around the world that killed thousands.
articles.abstract: A poisonous solvent sold by counterfeiters and mixed into drugs has figured in mass poisonings around the world that killed thousands.
articles.lead_paragraph: The kidneys fail first. Then the central nervous system begins to misfire. Paralysis spreads, making breathing difficult, then often impossible without assistance. In the end, most victims die.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Jake Hooker

articles.headline: Shock Radio Shrugs at Imus’s Fall and Roughs Up the Usual Victims
articles.snippet: Talk radio remains insidiously untamed, full of coarse, explicit banter, despite Don Imus’s firing.
articles.abstract: Talk radio remains insidiously untamed, full of coarse, explicit banter, despite Don Imus’s firing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost two weeks after CBS Radio fired Don Imus for his racially and sexually demeaning remarks about the Rutgers women’s basketball team, Nick Di Paolo opened his talk show on another CBS station in New York by mocking a manual that, he said, one of his bosses had given him that morning.

articles.headline: A Liberal Case for Gun Rights Sways Judiciary
articles.snippet: Top liberal law professors, embracing an individual right to own guns, have helped reshape the debate.
articles.abstract: Top liberal law professors, embracing an individual right to own guns, have helped reshape the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March, for the first time in the nation’s history, a federal appeals court struck down a gun control law on Second Amendment grounds. Only a few decades ago, the decision would have been unimaginable.

articles.headline: Ottaways Deplore Bid by Murdoch
articles.snippet: Members of the Ottaway family, a minority partner in Dow Jones, said a takeover by Rupert Murdoch would ruin the company and The Wall Street Journal.
articles.abstract: Members of the Ottaway family, a minority partner in Dow Jones, said a takeover by Rupert Murdoch would ruin the company and The Wall Street Journal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two members of the Ottaway family, a minority partner in Dow Jones & Company, released scathing statements yesterday saying that a takeover by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation would ruin Dow Jones and its crown jewel, The Wall Street Journal.

articles.headline: As Pope Heads to Brazil, a Rival Theology Persists
articles.snippet: Liberation theology, which the pope once called “a fundamental threat,” retains its appeal in Latin America.
articles.abstract: Liberation theology, which the pope once called “a fundamental threat,” retains its appeal in Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 2 — In the early 1980s, when Pope John Paul II wanted to clamp down on what he considered a dangerous, Marxist-inspired movement in the Roman Catholic Church, liberation theology, he turned to a trusted aide: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger.

articles.headline: Sarkozy Wins in France and Vows Break With Past
articles.snippet: Nicolas Sarkozy earned a decisive victory on Sunday over Ségolène Royal, keeping the right in power for another five years. Turnout was 84 percent of France’s registered voters.
articles.abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy earned a decisive victory on Sunday over Ségolène Royal, keeping the right in power for another five years. Turnout was 84 percent of France’s registered voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 6 — Nicolas Sarkozy, the passionate, pugnacious son of a Hungarian immigrant, was elected president of France on Sunday, promising a break with the past, a new style of leadership, and a renewal of relations with the United States and the rest of Europe.

articles.headline: Tech Investors Cull Start-Ups for Pentagon
articles.snippet: The Defense Department is using the nation’s top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies.
articles.abstract: The Defense Department is using the nation’s top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 — The nation’s military, in its search for the next surveillance system, bioterror vaccine or robot warrior, has decided to take a peek into the garage.

articles.headline: Beam It Down From the Web, Scotty
articles.snippet: New 3-D printers that transform three-dimensional plans online into solid objects could be in homes soon.
articles.abstract: New 3-D printers that transform three-dimensional plans online into solid objects could be in homes soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Sometimes a particular piece of plastic is just what you need. You have lost the battery cover to your cellphone, perhaps. Or your daughter needs to have the golden princess doll she saw on television. Now.

articles.headline: Hollywood Loves the Tiny Screen. Advertisers Don’t.
articles.snippet: Multiepisode cellphone series are growing in popularity but advertisers have been slow to migrate to the supersmall screen.
articles.abstract: Multiepisode cellphone series are growing in popularity but advertisers have been slow to migrate to the supersmall screen.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, May 6 — Superman has the power to leap tall buildings. But leaping onto a cellphone screen is proving a little trickier.

articles.headline: Once Again, Murdoch’s Siren Song
articles.snippet: Examining the News Corporation’s bid for Dow Jones, bearing in mind Rupert Murdoch’s unique business DNA.
articles.abstract: Examining the News Corporation’s bid for Dow Jones, bearing in mind Rupert Murdoch’s unique business DNA.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the thrill-ride version of the modern media mogul, delivered a particularly head-snapping jolt last week when the News Corporation said it intended to buy The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company for $5 billion. Now that some of the commotion has eased, it might be worth a few minutes to examine the proposal bearing in mind Mr. Murdoch’s unique business DNA.
